alert.note: Alert for Bucks (Pennsylvania) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly (New Jersey, Delaware, Southeastern Pennsylvania)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 09 at 4:08PM EST until January 10 at 5:42PM EST by NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Mount Holly NJ has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Pennsylvania... Neshaminy Creek At Langhorne affecting Bucks County. For the Neshaminy Creek...including Langhorne...Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT TO TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Neshaminy Creek at Langhorne. * WHEN...From late tonight to tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Water begins to overflow the lowest banks, on both sides of the creek, into adjacent wooded areas. At 9.0 feet, Flooding begins on Bridle Drive in Middletown Township. At 10.5 feet, Route 413, near Bridgeton Pike in Middletown Township, is subject to closures due to flooding. At 12.0 feet, Widespread flooding occurs on Bridle Drive in Middletown Township. The road becomes impassable. At 13.0 feet, Periwinkle Avenue in Middletown Township begins to flood. Flooding in also possible further downstream in the Croyden Section of Bristol Township, especially when the Delaware River tides are high. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:15 PM EST Tuesday the stage was 2.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight to a crest of 12.6 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 9.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.7 feet on 12/14/1996. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Stream Fld Observed Fcsts (7 pm) Crest Location Stg Stg Day/Time Wed Thu Stg Time Date Neshaminy Creek Langhorne 9.0 2.2 Tue 3 pm 5.9 3.6 12.6 7am 1/10 &&
info.instruction: Turn around...don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/phi. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 415 AM EST.
